change.item: Batch update to change subject links.

did.abstract: The Woodward, S.C. mss., 1767-1961, consist of correspondence, autographs and pictures of actors, actresses, managers, dramatists, musicians, and other persons connected with the theatre from the collection of Sidney C. Woodward, journalist.
did.physloc: ALF (Auxiliary Library Facility) - OVFlat; Lilly - Stacks

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.
Many collections are housed offsite; retrieval requires advance notice. Please make an appointment a minimum of one week in advance of your visit.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: S.C. Woodward was a journalist, art critic for the Christian Science Monitor, and director of the Casson Galleries.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into the following series: I. Correspondence, II. Bound materials, III. Printed, IV. Photgraphs, and V. Folders. Materials are arranged chronologically in Correspondence and then alphabetically for the rest of the series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The persons represented are principally from England and the United States. The correspondence relates in the main to theatrical and personal matters. The pictures in the collection consist of photographs, engravings, and pictures clipped from periodicals and newspapers. Also included are two volumes of commonplace books by Mary Frances Scott-Siddons.

userestrict.head: Usage Restrictions
userestrict.p: Photography and digitization may be restricted for some collections. Copyright restrictions may apply. Before publishing, researchers are responsible for securing permission from all applicable rights holders, then filling out the Permission to Publish form.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Item], Woodward, S. C. mss., Lilly Library, Indiana University, Bloomington, Indiana.

did.unittitle: Commonplace books by Mary Frances Scott-Siddons

odd.head: General
odd.p: All folders contain no contents, but feature handwritten notes and annotations in reference to each identified individual.
